speaker: Sam
text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Sam.

speaker: Neil
text: And I’m Neil.

speaker: Sam
text: In recent years new diets with names like ‘vegan’, ‘keto’ and ‘paleo’ have become very popular. Are you a vegetarian, Neil? Do you follow any particular diet?

speaker: Neil
text: Well, I eat lots of fresh fruit and vegetables and only a little meat from time to time.

speaker: Sam
text: Well, while many diets claim to improve health or help you lose weight, recent research shows that what counts is not what you eat but how your body reacts.

speaker: gut
text: Yes, and that reaction doesn’t happen where you might think – not in the brain, or tongue, or even the stomach, but in the gut – another name for the intestines - the long tube inside your body which digests food.

speaker: microbes
text: Inside everyone’s gut are millions of microbes – tiny living organisms, too small to see without a microscope. Some of them are good for us, some bad.

speaker: Neil
text: Microbes help digest food, but they influence our bodies more than we know. Think of them as chemical factories that cause our individual reaction to the food we eat.

speaker: Sam
text: This mix of gut microbes is unique and different for everyone, even identical twins.

speaker: Neil
text: And it’s the reason why some doctors now recommend a personalised diet, one that perfectly fits your own unique combination of microbes.

speaker: Sam
text: We’ll hear more soon, but first I have a question for you, Neil, and it’s about the gut - the tube which includes the large and small intestine. It’s very long - but how long exactly is the average adult’s gut? Is it:

speaker: Sam
text: a) 3.5 metres?

speaker: Sam
text: b) 5.5 metres? or,

speaker: Sam
text: c) 7.5 metres?

speaker: Neil
text: Well, everybody is different of course, but I’ll say on average the gut is b) 5.5 metres long.

speaker: Sam
text: OK, Neil, I’ll reveal the answer later in the programme.

speaker: Neil
text: Among the first to investigate gut microbes was Dr Tim Spector, author of bestselling book, The Diet Myth. He wanted to check whether the dietary advice he had heard and believed, advice like ‘eat little and often’ or ‘avoid fat’, was really true.

speaker: Sam
text: Listen as Dr Spector explains how he started to doubt some of this advice - ‘food myths’, he calls them - to BBC Radio 4 programme, The Life Scientific:

speaker: caloriesflimsy
text: All these so-called myths that I’d believed, whether it was about calories, about fats, when to eat, how to eat, were based on flimsy or no evidence, very old, very poor quality, and had been repeated so much that people didn’t think to question them.

speaker: calories
text: One of the food myths Dr Spector questioned was counting calories – the units which measure the amount of energy food provides.

speaker: flimsy flimsy
text: He discovered that much of the dietary advice he had heard was either incorrect or based on flimsy evidence. If evidence is flimsy, it’s weak and unconvincing.

speaker: Neil
text: As Dr Spector questioned these food myths, he remembered an earlier study involving identical twins, pairs of brothers or sisters with the same genes.

speaker: Sam
text: It was the surprising differences in weight between one twin and another that made Dr Spector realise that no two people have the same gut – even identical twins’ guts are different.

speaker: Neil
text: But, as he told BBC Radio 4’s, The Life Scientific, the discovery came in a very smelly way – by asking his volunteers to send samples of their poo in the post!

speaker: skinnystuck out of the crowd
text: We collected lots of these samples, sequenced them, and looked at twins where one was overweight and one was skinny… and we found in every case, the skinnier twin had a more diverse microbiome, greater numbers of different species and they also nearly always had high numbers of a couple of microbes that just stuck out of the crowd – and one was called christensenella and the other was called akkermansia.

speaker: skinny
text: Although genetically identical, one twin was overweight, while the other twin was skinny, or very thin.

speaker: Neil
text: Because the weight difference could not be explained genetically, Dr Spector suspected the microbes in the skinnier twin’s gut held the answer: the more diverse someone’s microbes, the better their gut was at digesting food, regulating fat and maintaining health.

speaker: stuck out of the crowd
text: Two microbes, christensenella and akkermansia, were especially effective. Dr Spector says these microbes stuck out of the crowd, meaning they were easy to notice for their positive effect.

speaker: Neil
text: And since everyone’s microbes are different, it follows that a personalised diet which selects the friendliest food for your gut, is best. Right, and all this talk of eating is making me hungry, so tell me, Sam, was my answer to your question, right?

speaker: Sam
text: Ah yes, I asked about the length of the gut in the average adult.

speaker: Neil
text: I said it was 5.5 metres.

speaker: Sam
text: Which was… the correct answer! Well done, Neil – that took ‘guts’, which is the second meaning of the word: courage.

speaker: gut
text: OK, let’s recap the vocabulary we’ve learned starting with gut – an informal word for the intestines, the tube which digests food from the stomach.

speaker: Microbes
text: Microbes are microscopic organisms living inside the body.

speaker: calorie
text: A calorie is a unit measuring how much energy food provides.

speaker: flimsy
text: If an argument or evidence is flimsy, it’s weak and hard to believe.

speaker: skinny
text: A skinny person is very thin.

speaker: sticks out of the crowd
text: And finally, if something sticks out of the crowd, it’s noticeable in a good way.

speaker: Neil
text: Unfortunately, our six minutes are up, but remember: look after your gut, and your gut will look after you! Goodbye!
